content.description: This is one of the finest traverses in Flagstaff. Start sitting at a big pinch and make a few powerful pulls out the short roof. Head right using many slopers and poor footholds to reach good pockets about halfway across the wall. Easier moves on deep pockets end at a jug just left of the tree. Match this hold and call it good. Topping out is possible but feels forced and needlessly destructive.
content.protection: A couple of pads and someone to move them and keep your head off the ground.
content.location: Start in back of the roof on the left side of the wall, climb out and traverse right.

content.description: Begin below the very steep bulge several feet left of the traverse's start (you will be on two opposing, crimpy sidepulls.) Make a big move to a slot, then over the bulge to a cluster of pockets. Pull through dishes to better holds and a faceful of moss, dirt and leaves (I don't think anyone would blame you for jumping off at this point.)
content.protection: A couple pads and a spot if you got it, this is a good problem to work on a solo trip.
content.location: Left of the start of the standard traverse, tackling the steep bulge.

content.description: Climb out the roof halfway across the traverse wall with super-fun moves. Join the traverse at good pockets and finish with its second half, ending just left of the tree at the last good jug. Don't bother topping out.
content.protection: A couple pads and a spotter.
content.location: Traverse the Traverse Wall, starting halfway through under the overhang.

content.description: Follow the sloping, left-trending arete, aiming for the scooped sloper just below the lip. Slippery and technical.
content.protection: A couple pads and a spotter, the landing slopes away and can be dangerous.

content.description: Two cliffs across the canyon from the Warm Up Wall. The Arkansas Wall is the left cliff, overhanging and dirty on the left side and roughly vertical but cleaner on the right. There are about half a dozen lines, including a classic technical arete and some freaky highballs. The Traverse Wall is steep, with a powerful left-right sloper traverse.
